title: The Central Limit Theorem
question_text: The annual salary of real estate agents varies from realtor to realtor. The distribution of annual salaries for all real estate agents in Florida is strongly skewed to the right. The Central Limit Theorem states:

choices.text: As more and more realtor's salaries are observed, the average salary gets even closer to the average $\mu$ of all realtors.
The average salary of a large number of real estate agents has a distribution with the same shape as the population distribution.
The average salary of a large number of real estate agents has a distribution with a similar shape (but not as strongly skewed) as the population distribution.
The average salary of a large number of real estate agents has a distribution that is close to Normal.
The average salary of a large number of real estate agents has a distribution that is exactly Normal.

solution:
Solution

The Central Limit Theorem states that if you have a population with mean $\mu$ and standard deviation $\sigma$ and take sufficiently large random samples from the population with replacement, then the distribution of the sample means will be approximately normally distributed.

So, Choice 'D' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice ‘A’ is incorrect. This is a correct statement - as more and more realtor's salaries are observed, the average salary does get even closer to the average $\mu$ of all realtors: $\mu_\bar{x} = \mu$. However, that is not a fact stated by the Central Limit Theorem.

Choice ‘B’ is incorrect. The Central Limit Theorem states the distribution of the sample mean will be approximately Normal, regardless of the shape of the population distribution.

Choice ‘C’ is incorrect. The Central Limit Theorem states the distribution of the sample mean will be approximately Normal, regardless of the shape of the population distribution.

Choice ‘E’ is incorrect. Very rarely will any distribution be exactly Normal. To say a distribution is exactly Normal implies exactly 68% of all observations lie within 1 standard deviation of the mean, exactly 95% of all observations lie within 2 standard deviations of the mean, and exactly 99.7% of all observations lie within 3 standard deviations of the mean.
